I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Nepal’s  10th  five-year  plan  (2002–2007),  which  is  also  the  Government’s  poverty 
reduction strategy paper, ends in July 2007. Given the political transition, which is expected to 
last 2–3 years, and the urgency of delivering development results in terms of peace dividends, 
the  Government  of  Nepal  (the  Government)  has  decided  to  prepare  a  3-year  interim 
development plan instead of a regular 5-year development plan, following the conclusion of the 
10th plan. In this context, the Government requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  support  preparation  of  the  proposed  3-year  interim 
development  plan  during  the  2006  Country  Programming  Mission.  The  vice  president 
(Operations 1) approved the TA concept paper on 31 October 2006.1 ADB fielded the TA Fact-
Finding Mission2 during 8–17 November 2006. The Mission’s main objectives were to identify 
the Government’s needs and priorities and to consult with relevant government agencies and 
other  stakeholders  on  the  scope  and  design  of  the  proposed  TA.  The  Mission  reached 
understanding with the Government on the TA’s objective, scope, costs and financing, tentative 
implementation arrangements, and counterpart support.3 Appendix 1 presents the design and 
monitoring framework for the TA. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  A decade-long conflict has affected Nepal’s social, economic, and political landscape. 
Physical infrastructure has been destroyed, thousands of people have been internally displaced, 
and development activities have been adversely affected. The average growth rate of Nepal’s 
gross domestic product declined from about 5% during the 1990s to less than 2.6% after 2001. 
Following dramatic political developments in April 2006, the Government and the Communist 
Party of Nepal, Maoists (CPN/M) initiated a peace process that led to the signing of a peace 
agreement between the two parties on 21 November 2006 and paved the way for lasting peace 
and stability. These achievements hold promise for ending the insurgency and establishing a 
new political order conducive to peace and prosperity. However, the transitional period presents 
significant challenges, including establishing a democratically elected government and reviving 
Nepal’s development activities.  
 
3.  While the ongoing peace process is a key priority, maintaining a focus on development 
is necessary to address the root causes of conflict, such as poverty and social exclusion. Peace 
is vital, but a lasting peace will need to be supported by accelerated economic growth that 
effectively  reaches  all  areas  and  sections  of  the  population  and  ensures  that  people’s 
socioeconomic aspirations are adequately met. In view of the conclusion of the 10th plan, 
Nepal’s investment and development priorities need to be reviewed and planning is needed for 
post-conflict reconstruction and rehabilitation in the changed political and development context. 
 
4.  The current Government is in a transitional phase and is focusing primarily on the peace 
process. Understanding that the political transition will require time, the Government is initiating 
preparation of a 3-year interim development plan that recognizes the need for formulating a 
development framework to guide Nepal’s development activities during the interim period. The 
3-year interim development plan will focus on rapid delivery of public services. While the interim 
plan will reflect and continue the strategic reforms and development priorities of the 10th plan

and will be aimed at achieving the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), it will be action 
oriented and its scope will be broadened to reflect Nepal’s development needs and challenges 
in the changed political context.  
 
5.  A centralized approach compounded by a lack of adequate prioritization undermines 
Nepal’s approach to planning. The country needs to plan its public resources use carefully to 
focus on poverty reduction and address the root causes of conflict. The interim development 
plan requires innovative approaches and a results-oriented priority investment program to cater 
to the needs of the poor and the disadvantaged. Another area of concern in relation to achieving 
development effectiveness is weak implementation and monitoring of past development plans.  
 
6.  The Government faces a number of challenges in the current political and security 
environment.  Key  challenges  in  relation  to  preparing  the  3-year  interim  development  plan 
include (i) the need to adopt a participatory planning process, (ii) the need to accommodate 
local priorities and capacities, and (iii) the need to accommodate and ensure consistency with 
other policies and public priorities. The interim development plan will need to be results based 
with clearly identified outcomes, outputs, and interventions that would help achieve them. It 
should  also  be  linked  to  the  Government’s  short,  medium,  and  long-term  development 
strategies aimed at meeting the MDGs. To this end, the 3-year interim development plan will 
serve as a building block of Nepal’s long-term development vision. 
 
7.  Priority setting is a crucial aspect of effective planning that requires detailed information, 
sound analysis, and good judgment, along with social consensus and ownership. The National 
Planning Commission (NPC) needs support with regard to the technical aspects of the plan 
preparation  and  the  participatory  processes needed  to  secure  stakeholder  consensus.  For 
preparing the 3-year interim development plan, the Government will build on work already 
undertaken,  and  in  particular  on  ADB-assisted  TAs  such as  economic  policy  network,  the 
regional development strategy, and the operationalization of managing for development results.4 
The plan will support institutionalizing poverty-focused participatory approaches and informed 
policy-making  processes  in  the  Government.  A  results-based  monitoring  and  evaluation 
mechanism will also be required to track the progress of implementation and provide necessary 
feedback. 
 
8.  The  Government  has  committed  through  the  FY2007  budget  to  hold  the  Nepal 
Development Forum (NDF) in the third quarter of FY2007. The Government has also indicated 
that it will prepare a longer-term vision with a more defined, 15 – 20 years strategy and set 
goals and targets in relation to the country’s socioeconomic development. However, these 
exercises  must  build  on  each  other  and  share  experiences  to  achieve  uniformity  and 
cohesiveness among various policy issues and documents. The timing presents opportunities 
for the interim development plan, the NDF, and the preparatory work for the long-term vision to 
supplement and complement each other, which is required in order to better allocate resources, 
enhance  the  implementation  progress,  and  facilitate  program  monitoring  and  evaluation. 
Formulation of a prioritized public investment plan requires preparing a public expenditure 
framework,  improving  service  delivery,  and aid  harmonization.  The NDF  could serve  as  a 
platform for sharing the major findings of the proposed TA with all development partners in 
relation to the prioritized public investment plan. The 3-year interim development plan supported

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA will help revive development activities based on the priorities agreed upon in the 
peace accord signed on 21 November 2006 and will address the structural causes of conflict 
and poverty. The outcome of the TA will consist of (i) support for the preparation of a 3-year 
interim development plan, (ii) facilitation of the NDF, and (iii) initial surveys and strategies 
needed for preparation of the country’s long-term vision. The TA is fully consistent with the 
operational priorities of the 2004 country strategy and program and the 2006 country operations 
business plan 2006,5 which underline the provision of support to the Government to strengthen 
its capacity to formulate national development plans. The TA will ensure that the 3-year interim 
development plan follows managing for development results approaches, which are a key 
element of ADB operations in and support for Nepal. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The 3-year interim development plan will be based on a review and assessment of 
various strategic documents prepared by the Government, development partners, and other 
stakeholders. These documents will include the poverty reduction strategy paper, the agriculture 
perspective plan, MDG progress reports, the MDG needs assessment, the water resources 
strategy, national water plan 2005, roads sector master plan, tourism master plan, health sector 
strategy,  the  decentralization  implementation  plan,  local  infrastructure  policy,  national  rural 
water supply and sanitation sector strategy, Nepal living standard survey, and other published 
and unpublished reports.  
 
11.  Based on the current economic environment and future prospects, a wide range of 
themes have been identified for the 3-year interim development plan that are directly relevant to 
poverty  reduction,  higher  economic  growth,  and  rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  activities. 
Given the support other development partners are to provide based on their specific expertise, 
the  areas  of  support  under  this  TA  include  (i)  employment,  labor,  and  human  resource 
development; (ii) rural infrastructure development; (iii) private sector development; (iv) social 
inclusion; (v) governance and decentralization; (vi) reconstruction and rehabilitation (short-term 
issue); (vii) agriculture; (viii) participatory management; and (ix) management for development 
results. The selected areas are consistent with ADB operations in Nepal. Given the evolving 
situation,  other  themes  and  issues  may  be  identified  for  inclusion  under  the  TA  during 
preparation of the 3-year interim development plan. 
 
12.  The interim development plan will incorporate the essential components of results-based 
development  planning  with  defined  targets  and  indicators  to  ensure  the  achievement  of 
development  objectives.  It  will  guide  effective  implementation  of  the  development  agenda, 
addressing the underlying causes of the conflict, gaining the support and confidence of all 
stakeholders, and pursuing approaches for building a lasting peace. A results-based framework 
for the interim development plan will be prepared to guide program development, resource 
allocation, implementation, and monitoring of progress and to provide feedback for decision

Business Plan (2007 – 2009). Manila.

4   
making. A detailed monitoring and evaluation action plan will also be prepared for results-based 
monitoring and evaluation. 
 
13.  The objectives of the TA will be realized through active participation by senior policy 
makers, entrepreneurs, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), individual experts, and other key 
stakeholders. The formulation of the development framework and the preparation of documents 
will adopt a participatory and bottom-up approach. Consultations will be undertaken both at the 
national and regional levels with local communities and grassroots organizations to identify local 
needs, strengthen ownership of the outputs. The participatory approach will help ensure the 
successful implementation of the 3-year interim development plan. Special consideration will be 
given to participation by disadvantaged communities and related organizations. NPC members 
and line ministry secretaries will play a key role in guiding the preparation of technical papers. A 
national seminar will be held with various stakeholders to help operationalize implementation of 
the  recommendations.  Similar  participatory  approaches  will  be  adopted  for  laying  the 
groundwork for the vision document under the guidance of the Government agency responsible 
for preparing it.  
 
14.  The  TA  activities  include  (i)  providing  support  to  the  structures  established  by  the 
Government for preparing the 3-year interim development plan, namely, the Steering Committee 
(chaired by the vice chair of the NPC and consisting of representatives of various Government 
agencies) and the NPC’s focal unit; (ii) holding consultative meetings, seminars, and workshops 
to strengthen the participatory approach and ownership of the process for formulating the 
development strategy; and (iii) facilitating the NDF and supporting the groundwork for preparing 
the vision document. The NPC’s focal unit will monitor and supervise the work of the TA 
consultants. The Steering Committee will meet periodically to develop the agenda for document 
preparation and to evaluate progress. The TA activities will encompass the preparation of 
technical papers that will be discussed at technical workshops.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $355,000 equivalent. ADB will provide $300,000 on a grant 
basis. ADB will finance the recruitment of the TA consultants and a major part of the costs of the 
studies, workshops, and seminars, as well as the costs incurred by the NPC’s focal unit. The 
Government will provide office accommodation, counterpart staff, facilities for seminars and 
meetings, and administrative expenses. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The NPC will be the Executing Agency and will be responsible for providing the strategic 
direction, developing appropriate modalities for overall implementation of the TA, and identifying 
appropriate  activities.  The  Steering  Committee  will  provide  leadership  and  guidance  for 
preparation  of  the  3-year  interim  development  plan  and  related  documents.  The  Steering 
Committee will meet as necessary, but at least (i) before finalization of the inception report, (ii) 
for preparation of an outline of the 3-year interim development plan for the NDF, and (iii) for 
finalization of the TA report. The subcommittees established by the Steering Committee will 
closely work with the TA consultants on relevant themes. Working committees on cross-cutting 
themes, which have been established at the NPC with the active participation of pertinent 
stakeholders (including the private sector and NGOs), will be the interlocutors of TA consultants. 
The NPC focal unit will facilitate, guide, and monitor day-to-day TA activities. The Ministry of

5
Finance, the Government agency responsible for leading preparation of the NDF, will provide 
guidance to the NPC’s focal unit in relation to support for facilitating the NDF and the ministry 
will have flexible use of funds intended for preparation of the NDF.  
 
17.  A national consulting firm will be recruited to undertake the TA activities. Only national 
consultants will be recruited because of the need for an in-depth understanding of the very 
unique local situation, and since participatory planning expertise is available in the country. The 
use  of  national  consultants  will  help  facilitate  ownership  by  an  honest  interaction  among 
stakeholders. Given the urgent need for TA support and considering that an outline of the draft 
3-year interim development plan is to be prepared by February 2007, the single source selection 
method will be used to recruit the consultants. New Era, a national firm, has been identified for 
recruitment to provide the consulting services. The firm possesses the necessary expertise in 
required areas and has provided satisfactorily consulting services to ADB in the past. The 
identified consulting firm will be recruited in line with Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by 
ADB and its Borrowers (2006, as amended from time to time). The sectoral and thematic 
studies, as well as the interim development plan, will be prepared by soliciting inputs through 
active  participation  by  all  stakeholders:  civil  society,  political  parties,  NGOs,  and  other 
development partners at the local, regional and national levels. 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 8 months from January to August 2007. A 
total of 48 person-months of national consulting services will be required. Appendix 3 presents 
the terms of reference for the consultants. The TA will provide limited computer equipment and 
motorcycles, which will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2006, 
as amended from time to time) and will be handed over to the agencies concerned upon 
completion of the TA. Tripartite meetings between the Government, the consultants, and ADB 
will  be  chaired  by  the  NPC  and  held  regularly  to  review  TA  activities.  By  July  2007,  the 
consultants will prepare a draft final report that will include (i) TA’s contribution to the 3-year 
interim development plan, (ii) a description of the use of TA funds, including the NDF, facilitation 
of the vision document and related outputs, (iii) recommendations for the use of remaining TA 
funds. 
 
19.  The team leader will coordinate TA activities; submit consolidated progress reports to 
the Steering Committee and the focal unit; and coordinate support to NPC’s focal unit and 
disburse funds in accordance with ADB regulations. The NPC’s focal unit will keep the Steering 
Committee informed about TA progress – and facilitate Steering Committee meetings. The team 
leader  will  prepare  an  inception  report  within  1  month  of  consultant  mobilization  and 
consolidated  quarterly  progress  reports  on  TA  activities.  An  outline  of  the  3-year  interim 
development plan will be prepared for the NDF. The TA will also include required outputs for the 
vision document. A draft final report will be prepared no later than 1 month before completion of 
the TA and the final TA report will incorporate comments on the draft final report and will be 
completed by the end of the TA. Three copies of all reports will be submitted to the focal unit, to 
the Steering Committee, and to ADB.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Nepal for Supporting Preparation of the 3-Year Interim Development Plan, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Project Management and Planning Expert and Team Leader (8 person-months) 
1.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
(i)  Prepare  the  3-year  interim  development  plan  in  close  consultation  with  the 
Government and with help from the deputy team leader and other consultants.  
(ii)  Provide support to the overall management of the technical assistance (TA) and its 
implementation  activities  and  ensure  timely  submission  of  individual  consulting 
reports. 
(iii)  Provide  overall  guidance  to  the  individual  consultants  in  terms  of  the  strategic 
direction and technical competencies of the outputs. 
(iv)  Work in close consultation with the National Planning Commission’s focal unit, the 
Steering Committee, and working committees and be responsible for addressing 
needs identified during consultations and tripartite meetings.  
(v)  Help identify the necessary studies and undertake activities required for the Nepal 
Development Forum. 
(vi)  Facilitate  preparatory  work  and  workshops  for  the  Government’s  long-term 
development vision. 
(vii)  Organize  and  participate  in  meetings,  workshops,  and  seminars  to  review  and 
discuss the findings of the papers prepared by the various working groups. 
(viii)  Prepare periodic reports. 
(ix)  Ensure the consistency of the interim development plan with the Government’s 
strategies in relation to the Millennium Development Goals and its poverty reduction 
strategy paper and other strategic documents. 
(x)  Undertake  other  tasks  identified  by  the  Steering  Committee  and  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). 
 
B.  Rural Infrastructure Development Specialist (Engineer) and Deputy Team Leader (8 
person-months) 
2.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
(i)  Assume overall responsibility for the TA in the absence of the team leader. 
(ii)  Support operational management of the TA in accordance with the TA document 
and the policies and procedures for execution of the TA. 
(iii)  Prepare and update TA work plans and submit them to ADB and the National 
Planning Commission. 
(iv)  Provide overall supervision and coordination of the consultants’ work to ensure the 
production of the corresponding TA outputs. 
(v)  Manage the funds for procuring equipment and organizing seminars, workshops, 
and meetings in close coordination with the Steering Committee. 
(vi)  Support  the  team  leader  in  preparing  periodic  TA  progress  reports  and  other 
documents identified in the TA.  
(vii)  Oversee  and  coordinate  overall  TA  implementation  activities  and  ensure  timely 
submission of individual consulting reports. 
(viii)  Help finalize the medium-term public investment plan based on the socioeconomic 
development of the country with the help of the committees, consultative meetings, 
and consultants. 
(ix)  Work with the TA team leader to prepare an infrastructure development plan (roads, 
electricity, and irrigation) to help improve productive capacities, increase investment, 
and address regional balance.

(x)  Review and suggest mechanisms for enhancing all types of connectivity to remote 
areas and exploiting Nepal’s locational advantage. 
(xi)  Ensure the implementability of the TA’s recommendations. 
(xii)  Participate in the meetings, workshops, and seminars to review and discuss the 
findings of the reports and obtain consensus on related policy recommendations. 
(xiii)  Undertake other tasks identified by the Steering Committee and ADB. 
 
C.  Employment, Labor, and Human Resource Development Specialist (4 person-months) 
3.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
(i)  Work with the TA team leader to prepare a strategy, identify key challenges, and 
recommend ways to generate more employment.  
(ii)  Help prepare a plan for managing foreign workers and remittances and addressing 
unemployment among young people and the educated to achieve higher economic 
growth and poverty reduction.  
(iii)  Review and recommend ways to improve Nepal’s participation in the international 
labor market and related skills development strategies. 
(iv)  Participate in the meetings, workshops, and seminars to review and discuss the 
findings of the reports and obtain consensus on related policy recommendations. 
(v)  Undertake other tasks identified by the Steering Committee and ADB. 
 
D.  Private Sector Development Specialist (3 person-months) 
4.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
(i)  Work  with  the  team  leader  to  identify  key  challenges  and  recommendations, 
especially in relation to dismantling the barriers that reduce productivity, investment, 
and economic growth; improving regulatory mechanisms; and improving productive 
capacities to attract private sector investment. 
(ii)  Suggest ways to increase the role of the private sector in growth and development. 
(iii)  Participate in the meetings, workshops, and seminars to review and discuss the 
findings of the reports and obtain consensus on related policy recommendations. 
(iv)  Undertake other tasks identified by the Steering Committee and ADB. 
 
E.  Social Inclusion Specialist (4 person-months) 
5.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
(i)  Work with the team leader and develop a practical and implementable plan for 
social  inclusion  in  order  to  bring  those  excluded  into  the  mainstream  of  the 
development process, improve their livelihoods, and implement affirmative action. 
(ii)  Undertake research and analysis and provide recommendations for deprived areas 
and excluded communities.  
(iii)  Participate in the meetings, workshops, and seminars to review and discuss the 
findings of the reports and obtain consensus on related policy recommendations. 
(iv)  Undertake other tasks identified by the Steering Committee and ADB. 
 
F.  Governance and Decentralization specialist (4 person-months) 
 
6.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
(i)  Support  the  team  leader  in  devising  mechanisms  for  incorporating  the  key 
components of governance in the interim plan.

(iii)  Participate in the meetings, workshops, and seminars to review and discuss the

(iv)  Undertake other tasks identified by the Steering Committee and ADB. 
 
G.  Reconstruction and Rehabilitation (3 person-months) 
 
7.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
(i)  Works with the team leader to identify key areas for reconstruction and rehabilitation, 
the challenges involved, and ways to overcome the challenges.   
(ii)  Prepare a strategy for rehabilitating displaced people and reconstructing physical 
infrastructure damaged by conflict.  
(iii)  Conduct research as required by the task forces and prepare draft policy papers. 
(iv)  Participate in the meetings, workshops, and seminars to review and discuss the 
findings of the reports and obtain consensus on related policy recommendations. 
(v)  Undertake other tasks identified by the Steering Committee and ADB. 
 
H.  Participatory Management Specialist (3 person-months) 
8.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
(i)  Work  with  the  team  leader  to  identify  key  areas  for  people’s  participation,  the 
challenges involved, and ways to overcome the challenges. 
(ii)  Prepare a strategy for participatory preparation of the interim development plan. 
(iii)  Facilitate the use of participatory approaches and participation by disadvantaged 
communities in the process for achieving individual outputs and devising the overall 
interim development plan.  
(iv)  Participate in the meetings, workshops, and seminars to review and discuss the 
findings of the reports and obtain consensus on related policy recommendations. 
(v)  Undertake other tasks identified by the Steering Committee and ADB. 
 
I.  Managing for Development Results Specialist (2 person-months) 
9.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
(i)  Work with the team leader to identify key areas for MfDR, the challenges involved, 
and ways to overcome the challenges.  
(ii)  Prepare a results framework with outcomes, outputs, and targets and a linkage to 
the budget for the 3-year interim development plan.  
(iii)  Prepare  a  monitoring  and  evaluation  action  plan  to  assess  the  progress  of 
implementation and provide feedback. 
(iv)  Participate in the meetings, workshops, and seminars to review and discuss the 
findings of the reports and obtain consensus on related policy recommendations. 
(v)  Undertake other tasks identified by the Steering Committee and ADB.
